subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... Yes, somewhere in some remote region, there is someone whose dialect is so crazy that he actually pronounces one of these pairs identical. Like, me!
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:
>

>
> [*] May involve further mergers.
>
> It's only rough because there are other mergers in various dialects
> that aren't represented here: psalm/sum, bud/bird, pin/pen, mit/meet,
> met/mat, meet/mate, bit/bet, cot/coat, rod/ride, pride/proud, line/loin,
> merry/Mary/merry, hurry/furry, furry/ferry, cheer/chair, fur/fair,
> stir/steer, tower/tire, tower/tar, tire/tar, cure/fir, card/cord. Yes,
> somewhere there is a group of people who pronounce each pair of words
> identically (and not just those words, many other pairs too).
>

Yes, somewhere in some remote region, there is someone whose dialect is
so crazy that he actually pronounces one of these pairs identical. Like,
me! Really, I actually pronounce cheer/chair identical. I never even
though it possible to pronounce do distinguish them in speech. It was
just tonight that I was talking about this subject with my girlfriend,
undoubtedly boring her to death, that it came up that I pronounce
"pair," "peer," "pier," and "pear" in the same way. She couldn't believe
I didn't distinguish them in speech.

So there you go.

Paul
